bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 13, [1900]

div1.p: Emilie Lawrence Reed will not visit Cuba. Reed discusses additional research questions, including the larvae of infected mosquitoes. The experiment involving the injection of infected blood was successful.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 13, [1900]
div1.opener:
Columbia Barracks,
December 13th,
Sunday night.
My darling wifie:
div1.p:
Yesterday I
had not only a letter from sweet-
-est “oomsey”, but one, also, from
dear little Annapolis Reed.
What sweet letters they were!
No talking about bills & such
disagreeable subjects, but just
plain, sensible, nice letters.
So my sweet wifie thinks
that she had better stay
where she is and not venture
on the Atlantic at this
season of the year. I am so
very glad that you have con-
cluded not to come, as it
worried me so to know that
my sweetheart wanted to
come and I couldn't consent to
it- You will be so much more
comfortable where you are-
I see no reason why my
darling Miss Gouty and the
charming Miss Annapolis
shouldn't have a good time
this week with all those at-
tractions at the theatres -- with
Mand Adams and the Divine
Sarah, you ought to manage
to “worry along” for a while.
While I think of it, mother, dear,
there will be five mails here-
after, each week, instead
of three as heretofore- So that
you can write just as often
as you please and when you
please- Isn't that fine? Hur-
ry up now, dearest heart,
and write five times a week!
Another thing, mother, dear: please
give that precious little scholar
one dollar for her father- I would
have sent it right away, but
I sent dearest “oomsey” nearly
all I had & haven't a dollar
bill left- You just let her have
it for being such a sweet child
and I will pay you back when
I come- Don't forget this, please -
concerning the question whether
the larvae of the infected mosquito
can convey the disease, we haven't
yet been able to say- You see
we could only take larvae hatched
from the eggs of those insects that
have already conveyed the disease
& after they have conveyed it-
We have only, to-day, our first
eggs from such insects which
we will try, of course - Since
I last wrote you, we have infec-
ted two men by injecting the
blood of a case under the skin
of the healthy individual- This shows
that the parasite is in the general
circulation and that yellow fever, like
Malaria, can be conveyed by the mos-
quito's bite or by infection of the
blood- Isn't that interesting?
Never mind, lovie, dear, what the
profession thinks now, they will
come around after awhile-
No one who has seen our cases
and the circumstances under which
they were infected, but admits,
at once, that we have conclu-
sively proven the whole thing-
How is that gouty toe, Miss
Farmer-lady? Still drinking only
milk and mineral waters? my!
but that ought to be fattening!
wait till I get back, if you want
to see eating! Did I tell you that
I weigh 148 lbs. in my light clothing?
I am getting to be actually too fat!
Good-night, you sweet, sweet girls!
Love & kisses for my own precious
children- Boo! Boo! You Joys!
